name: Access Control
description: The practice of limiting access to computer systems and data to authorized users, preventing unauthorized entry or disclosure.

name: Access Control List
description: A list of rules that specify which users or systems can access certain resources, helping to manage access control and permissions.

name: Access Point
description: A device that allows wireless devices to connect to a wired network, providing network access in Wi-Fi environments.

name: Access Token
description: A credential used to access resources or services, often in OAuth or API authentication, granting temporary permission.

name: Account Lockout
description: A security measure that locks a user out of their account after multiple failed login attempts, preventing unauthorized access.

name: Adaptive Authentication
description: Authentication methods that adjust based on the risk profile of a user or transaction, increasing security in response to potential threats.

name: Address Resolution Protocol (ARP)
description: A protocol used to map IP addresses to MAC addresses on a local network, facilitating data transmission.

name: Address Space Layout Randomization (ASLR)
description: A security technique that randomizes the memory locations of system processes to thwart attacks like buffer overflow exploits.

name: Advanced Persistent Threat
description: In an APT attack, a threat actor uses the most sophisticated tactics and technologies to penetrate a high-profile network. APTs aim to stay ‘under the radar’ and explore the network while remaining undetected for weeks, months, and even years. APTs are most often used by nation-state threat actors wishing to cause severe disruption and damage to the economic and political stability of a country. They can be considered the cyber equivalent of espionage ‘sleeper cells’.

name: Advanced Threat Protection
description: Advanced Threat Protection (ATP) are security solutions that defend against sophisticated malware or hacking attacks targeting sensitive data. Advanced Threat Protection includes both software and managed security services.

name: Adware
description: Adware bombards users with endless ads and pop-up windows and causes a nuisance to the user experience. Adware can also pose a real danger to devices and the unwanted ads can include malware or redirect user searches to malicious websites that collect personal data about users. Adware programs are often built into freeware or shareware programs, where the adware operator collects an indirect fee for using the program. Adware programs usually do not show themselves in the system in any way. Adware programs seldom include a de-installation procedure, and attempts to remove them manually may cause the original carrier program to malfunction.

name: AI Security
description: The protection of AI systems from attacks and vulnerabilities that can compromise the integrity of machine learning models and data.

name: Air Gap
description: Physically isolating a computer or network from the internet or other unsecured networks to prevent unauthorized access or data transfer.

name: Algorithms
description: Mathematical functions used in cryptography and security protocols to ensure data confidentiality and integrity.

name: Analog Hole
description: A vulnerability that allows the unauthorized copying of digital content, enabling copyright violations and data theft.

name: Anonymization
description: The process of making data anonymous to protect privacy, ensuring that individuals cannot be readily identified from the data.

name: Anomaly-Based Intrusion Detection System (IDS)
description: A security system that detects attacks by identifying unusual or abnormal behavior on a network, enhancing security by recognizing threats that signature-based systems may miss.

name: Anti-Botnet
description: Anti-Botnet tools automatically generate botnet checks when a user browses a website. If a risk is detected, it sends back a warning message to the device. The most common anti-botnet solution is CAPTCHA (Completely Automated Public Turing test to tell Computers and Humans Apart).

name: Anti-Malware
description: Anti-Malware is a program designed to protect computers and networks against any threats or attacks from viruses such as adware, spyware, and any such other malicious programs.

name: Anti-Phishing
description: Anti-Phishing protects users from fraudulent websites, often perfect replicas of legitimate websites, undetectable to the human eye. Protection is enforced by detecting fraudulent emails, and by blocking phishing websites.

name: Anti-Replay Attack
description: A security mechanism that prevents attackers from interceptingand reusing data, maintaining data confidentiality and integrity.

name: Anti-Virus
description: Anti-Virus solutions integrate the latest generation of virus detection technology to protect users from viruses, spyware, trojans, and worms that can infect equipment through email or internet browsing.

name: Anti-Virus Signature
description: Anti-Virus solutions integrate the latest generation of virus detection technology to protect users from viruses, spyware, trojans, and worms that can infect equipment through email or internet browsing.

name: API Gateway
description: A server that acts as an API front-end, providing security, load balancing, and other essential functions for API management and protection.

name: API Key
description: A unique code used to authenticate and gain access to an API or service ensuring secure communication between applications and resources.

name: API Security
description: Protection of Application Programming Interfaces from unauthorized access, misuse, and vulnerabilities that may expose data or functionality.

name: Applet
description: A small application or program that runs within a web browser, often used for web-based interactivity.

name: Application Layer
description: The top layer of the OSI model, handling communication between applications and responsible for data exchange.

name: Application Firewall
description: A security mechanism that filters and monitors incoming and outgoing traffic to protect applications from threats and unauthorized access.

name: Application Layer Firewall
description: A firewall that operates at the application layer of the OSI model, monitoring and filtering traffic based on the specific application protocols.

name: Application Security Testing (AST)
description: The process of testing applications for vulnerabilities and weaknesses, including static analysis, dynamic analysis, and penetration testing.

name: Application Whitelisting
description: Allowing only approved applications to run on a system while blocking all others, enhancing security by restricting unauthorized software.

name: AppSec
description: Abbreviation for Application Security, encompassing practices and technologies to secure software applications from vulnerabilities and attacks.

name: Attack Surface
description: The potential entry points or vulnerabilities in a system or application that can be exploited by attackers to gain unauthorized access.

name: Attack Surface Analysis
description: Identifying patterns or signatures of known malware to detect and remove threats from computer systems, enhancing cybersecurity.

name: Attack Surface Reduction (ASR)
description: Techniques and strategies used to minimize the attack surface of a system, reducing the number of potential vulnerabilities and attack vectors.

name: Attack Vector
description: An Attack Vector is the collection of all vulnerable points by which an attacker can gain entry into the target system. Attack vectors include vulnerable points in technology as well as human behavior, skillfully exploited by attackers to gain access to networks. The growth of IoT devices and (Work from Home) have greatly increased the attack vector, making networks increasingly difficult to defend.

name: Attribute-Based Access Cotrol (ABAC)
description: Access control based on attributes of users, systems, and resources, allowing dynamic and flexible permissions.

name: ARP Spoofing
description: A technique where an attacker associates their MAC address with a legitimate IP address in a network, enabling unauthorized access.

name: Asset Inventory
description: Maintaining a comprehensive record of all hardware, software, and data assets within an organization to ensure effective security management.

name: Asymmetric Encryption
description: A cryptographic method that uses different keys for encryption and decryption, enhancing security by separating keys.

name: Asymmetric Encryption Standard (AES)
description: A widely used symmetric encryption algorithm that ensures data confidentiality and integrity through strong encryption.

name: Asymmetric Key Encryption
description: a cryptographic method that enhances security by using separate keys for encryption and decryption.

name: Audit Trail
description: A chronological record of system and network activities, including user actions, for monitoring, compliance, and forensic analysis.

name: Authentication
description: Authentication is the process of verifying the identity of a user or piece of information and the veracity of the information provided. In computing, it is the process of identifying a person or system with a username, password, etc. Authentication helps individuals and systems gain authorization based on their identity and prevent unauthorized access.

name: Authentication Factor
description: The method or component used to confirm the identity of a user, such as passwords, biometrics, or security tokens.

name: Authentication Protocol
description: A standardized method for verifying the identity of a user or system, such as the use of usernames and passwords.

name: Authentication Token
description: A physical or digital device used for two-factor authentication, providing an additional layer of security.

name: Authentication Server
description: A server responsible for verifying user credentials during the authentication process.

name: Authorization
description: The process of granting or denying access permissions to users or systems, ensuring that only authorized entities have access to specific resources.

name: Avalanche Effect
description: A cryptographic concept where a small change in input data produces a significantly different output, enhancing the security of encryption algorithms.

name: Backdoor
description: Attackers use a Backdoor to gain access to a computer or a network. A programmer may bypass security steps and gain access to a computer through trapdoor programs, in the event of an attack on the computer system or networks. Attackers may also use such mechanisms to enter computers or networks without proper permission.

name: Backscatter
description: Unintentional radiofrequency or electromagnetic radiation reflected back toward its source, often associated with radar or wireless communication.

name: Backup
description: Backup is the process of creating duplicate copies of data, files, or entire systems to ensure that if the original data is lost, damaged, or compromised, a copy can be restored. Backups are typically stored on separate media or in a different location to protect against data loss due to hardware failures, data corruption, accidental deletions, or other unexpected events.

name: Backup and Recovery
description: Backup and recovery is the process of creating copies of data to ensure its availability in case of data loss or a cyber-incident.

name: Backup Key
description: A cryptographic key used for data backup and recovery, ensuring that data can be restored if the primary encryption key is lost or compromised. 101. Business Impact Criticality: The assessment of how critical a particular business process or function is to the overall operations and success of an organization.

name: Bad Data
description: Data that is incorrect, corrupted, or unusable due to errors, inconsistencies, or inaccuracies.

name: Banker Trojan
description: A Banker Trojan is a malicious computer program that intercepts sensitive personal information and credentials for accessing online bank or payment accounts.

name: Bannner Ad
description: An online advertisement typically displayed at the top, bottom, or sides of a web page. It often includes images, text, and links to promote products or services.

name: Bannner Grabbing
description: Banner grabbing is the process of collecting information about a target system, such as its operating system or version, by analyzing banners sent by network services.

name: Base64
description: A binary-to-text encoding scheme used to represent binary data as ASCII text. It is commonly used in data transmission and storage, including encoding email attachments.

name: Baseline
description: A reference point or starting point that serves as a standard for comparison. In various contexts, a baseline can be used to measure progress, changes, or deviations.

name: Bastion Host
description: A highly secured and fortified computer or server that is strategically placed on a network to protect it from unauthorized access, often used in firewalls and security setups.

name: Beaconing
description: Beaconing is the periodic transmission of data by malware to a command and control server to signal its presence and status. It is a term used in the context of computer networking and wireless communication. It refers to the process where a device, often a wireless access point or networked device, periodically sends out a signal or beacon to announce its presence and provide information to other devices in the vicinity.

name: Behavior Analysis
description: Behavior analysis is the study of patterns and activities within a network to detect abnormal or suspicious behavior that may indicate a cyber threat.

name: Behavior-Based Detection
description: Behavior-based detection analyzes the behavior of  software or users to identify abnormal or malicious activities

name: Behavior Profiling
description: The process of analyzing and creating a profile of an individual's online or digital behavior, often used in cybersecurity to detect abnormal or malicious activities.

name: Bit Torrent
description: BitTorrent is a peer-to-peer file-sharing protocol that is sometimes used to distribute malicious software, making it a concern for cybersecurity.

name: Binary Code
description: Binary code is a system of representing data and instructions using a series of 1s and 0s, which is fundamental in computing and cybersecurity.

name: Binary Large Object (BLOB)
description: A data type in databases and computer systems used to store binary data, such as images, audio, or video files.

name: Biometric Authentication
description: Unique physical or behavioral characteristics of an individual, such as fingerprints, facial recognition, or iris scans, used for identity verification and security purposes.

name: Biometric Data
description: Data used as a reference point for biometric authentication, such as a fingerprint template or facial recognition data used to verify an individual's identity.

name: Biometric Reference Data
description: Biometric authentication uses unique physical or behavioral traits, such as fingerprints or facial recognition, to verify a user's identity.

name: Bit
description: Short for 'binary digit', it is the smallest unit of digital data, representing a 0 or 1 in binary code, used in computing and digital communication.

name: BIOS (Basic Input/Output System)
description: A firmware used to initialize and control hardware components in a computer, typically stored in a computer's motherboard. It is responsible for the boot-up process and hardware communication.

name: Black Hat SEO
description: Unethical and manipulative techniques used to improve a website's search engine ranking, often violating search engine guidelines and resulting in penalties.

name: Blacklist
description: Blacklist, Blocklist, or Denylist is a basic access control mechanism that allows elements such as email addresses, users, passwords, URLs, IP addresses, domain names, file hashes, etc. through the system, except those explicitly mentioned which are denied access.

name: Blacklistable
description: The quality of being eligible to be placed on a blacklist due to malicious or undesirable behavior.

name: Blastware
description: Malicious software designed to destroy or render data or hardware irrecoverable, typically used in cyberattacks to cause permanent damage.

name: Blind SQL Injection
description: A type of SQL injection attack where an attacker sends malicious SQL queries to a web application's database without receiving direct feedback. They 'blindly' infer information from the application's response.

name: Blockchain Security
description: Blockchain security focuses on protecting decentralized ledgers from unauthorized access and tampering.

name: Block Cipher
description: A method of encrypting data in fixed-size blocks, where the same block of plaintext will always produce the same block of ciphertext. This is commonly used in encryption algorithms.

name: Blue Team
description: In the context of cybersecurity, the 'Blue Team' refers to the group within an organization responsible for defending against cyberattacks. They often work in contrast to the 'Red Team', which simulates attackers to test defenses. Blockchain security focuses on protecting decentralized ledgers from unauthorized access and tampering.

name: Bluetooth
description: A wireless communication technology standard that allows devices to connect and exchange data over short distances, commonly used for connectingsmartphones, headphones, and other peripherals.

name: Bootable Disk
description: A storage medium, such as a CD, DVD, or USB drive, that contains the necessary data and instructions to start a computer and load an operating system.

name: Boot Sector
description: The section of a storage device (like a hard drive or USB) that contains the information necessary for the device to boot up and load an operating system.

name: Bot
description: A Bot is a program that automates actions on behalf of an agent for some other program or person and is used to carry out routine tasks. Their use for malicious purposes includes spam distribution, credentials harvesting, and the launching of DDoS attacks

name: Bot Herder
description: An individual or entity responsible for creating and controlling a botnet, typically used for malicious purposes, such as launching cyberattacks.

name: Bot Imitation
description: The act of creating a bot that mimics human behavior or interaction to avoid detection, often used in social engineering or malicious activities.

name: Botnet
description: A Botnet is a collection of compromised computers running malicious programs that are controlled remotely by a C&C (command & control) server operated by a cyber-criminal. Cybercriminals exercise remote control through automated processes (bots) in public IRC channels or websites. (Such websites may either be run directly by the ‘bot herder,’ or they may be legitimate websites that have been subverted for this purpose.)

name: Botmaster
description: A person or entity that controls a network of compromised computers (botnet) and can issue commands to the individual bots for various purposes, including cyberattacks.

name: Breach
description: Browser security involves securing web browsers to protect against vulnerabilities, malicious extensions, and browser-based attacks.

name: Browser Security
description: Browser security involves securing web browsers to protect against vulnerabilities, malicious extensions, and browser-based attacks.

name: Bricking
description: Rendering a device, such as a smartphone or computer, completely inoperable, essentially turning it into a 'brick'. This can happen due to software errors or unauthorized modifications.

name: Brute-Force Attack
description: This is a method for guessing a password (or the key used to encrypt a message) that involves systematically trying a high volume of possible combinations of characters until the correct one is found. One way to reduce the susceptibility to a Brute Force Attack is to limit the number of permitted attempts to enter a password – for example, by allowing only three failed attempts and then permitting further attempts only after 15 minutes.

name: Brute-Force Cracking
description: A method of attempting to gain access to a system or data by trying all possible combinations of usernames and passwords until the correct one is found, typically used in hacking.

name: Buffer
description: A buffer overflow occurs when a program writes more data into a buffer (temporary storage) than it can handle, potentially leading to code execution by an attacker.

name: Buffer Overflow
description: A temporary storage area in computer memory used to hold data while it is being transferred from one place to another. Buffers are often used to manage data between different speeds or types of devices.

name: Bug
description: A software or hardware flaw or error that can cause unintended behavior, malfunction, or security vulnerabilities in a system.

name: Bug Bounty Program
description: A bug bounty program is a reward system where organizations offer incentives to ethical hackers who discover and report security vulnerabilities.

name: Bulk Transport
description: The movement of large quantities of goods or data from one location to another, typically used in logistics and data transfer contexts.

name: Business Continuity Plan
description: A Business Continuity Plan is an organization’s playbook for how to operate in an emergency situation, like a massive cyberattack. The business continuity plan provides safeguards against a disaster and outlines the strategies and action plan on how to continue business as usual in the event of any large-scale cyber event.

name: Business Disruption
description: The term Business Disruption refers to any interruption in the usual way that a system, process, or event works. Cyberattacks cause disruption to business operations and the associated risk of losses to the organization.

name: Business Email Account
description: An email account used for business communication, typically associated with a professional domain name and used by employees or representatives of a company.

name: Business Email Address
description: The email address associated with a business or organization, typically using the business's domain name, and used for professional communication.

name: Business Email Compromise Plan (BEC)
description: A type of cyberattack where an attacker compromises a business email account to impersonate an executive or employee and conduct fraudulent activities, such as wire transfers or sensitive data theft.

name: Business Impact
description: The effect or consequence of a specific event or situation on a business, often related to financial, operational, or reputational aspects.

name: Business Impact Ananlysis (BIA)
description: The term Business Disruption refers to any interruption in the usual way that a system, process, or event works. Cyberattacks cause disruption to business operations and the associated risk of losses to the organization. An evaluation of the potential consequences of a disruptive event on a business, typically used to assess the impact on operations, revenue, reputation, and other critical factors.

name: Business Process
description: A series of interrelated tasks and activities within an organization that work together to achieve a specific business goal or objective.

name: Business Process Compromise
description: A security breach in which an attacker infiltrates and manipulates critical business processes, potentially causing financial loss or damage to an organization.

name: Business Process Compromise Threat
description: The potential threat to a business process where an attacker infiltrates and manipulates the process for malicious purposes, potentially causing financial or operational damage.

name: Business Process Criticality
description: The assessment of how critical a particular business process is to the overall operations and success of an organization.

name: Business Partner
description: Another organization or entity with which a company collaborates or has a business relationship to achieve common goals, such as suppliers, customers, or strategic allies.

name: Business Risk
description: The potential for adverse events or circumstances that may affect an organization's ability to achieve its objectives, including financial, operational, and reputational risks.

name: BYOC
description: Bring Your Own Computer (BYOC) is a fairly recent enterprise computing trend by which employees are encouraged or allowed to bring and use their own personal computing devices to perform some or part of their job roles, specifically personal laptop computers.

name: BYOD
description: Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) is a policy of the organization allowing, encouraging or requiring its employees to use their personal devices such as smartphones, Tablet PCs, and laptops for official business purposes and accessing enterprise systems and data.

name: BYOL
description: Bring Your Own Laptop (BYOL) is a specific type of BYOC by which employees are encouraged or allowed to bring and use their own laptops to perform some or part of their job roles, including possible access to enterprise systems and data.

name: Byte
description: A unit of digital information that consists of 8 bits, often used to represent a single character or a small amount of data in computing.

name: CAPTCHA
description: A CAPTCHA (Completely Automated Public Turing test to tell Computers and Humans Apart) is a challenge-response test commonly used by websites to verify the user is a real human and not a bot. They can include simple arithmetic and questions about images, that bots have difficulty answering.

name: Certificate
description: In the context of cybersecurity, a certificate is a digital document that verifies the identity of an entity, such as a website or user, and encrypts data transmissions to ensure secure communication.

name: Clickjacking
description: Clickjacking involves tricking someone into clicking on one object on a web page while they think they are clicking on another. The attacker loads a transparent page over the legitimate content on the web page so that the victim thinks they are clicking on a legitimate item when they are really clicking on something on the attacker’s invisible page. This way, the attacker can hijack the victim’s click for their own purposes. Clickjacking could be used to install malware, gain access to one of the victim’s online accounts, or enable the victim’s webcam.

name: Clientless
description: Clientless refers to a program that is run entirely from the network, without requiring any installation of software on the endpoint device running the program. Code Injection is commonly used by malware to evade detection by antivirus and anti-malware programs by injecting malicious code into a legitimate process. This way the legitimate process serves as camouflage so all anti-malware tools can see running is the legitimate process and thus obfuscates the malicious code execution.

name: Cloud
description: You already utilize cloud computing if you use Gmail for email, Google Drive for document storage, or Netflix to stream your favorite movies. These services are all built on the cloud. cloud computing is providing on-demand services over the internet.If you want to run a business and you need to keep user data and you decide to do it on a hard drive, you will need a lot of storage space and a tech staff for it.Cloud service providers like Microsoft Azure, AWS, and Google Cloud, which offer on-demand services and are both cost-effective and low-risk in terms of security, make this procedure simple.

name: Cloud Security
description: Cloud security focuses on protecting data and resources stored in cloud computing environments. It includes measures to ensure the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data in cloud services.

name: Compliance
description: Compliance in cybersecurity refers to adhering to legal, regulatory, and industry-specific standards and requirements to ensure the security and privacy of data. Organizations must follow compliance guidelines to avoid legal issues and data breaches.

name: COTS
description: Commercial off-the Shelf or Commercially Available off the Shelf (COTS) products are packaged solutions that are then adapted to satisfy the needs of the purchasing organization, rather than the commissioning of custom-made, or bespoke, solutions.

name: Credential
description: Credentials are pieces of information, such as usernames and passwords, that are used to authenticate and verify the identity of users accessing computer systems, websites, or applications.

name: Critical Infrastructure
description: Critical Infrastructure represents the fundamental systems of an organization that is important for its survival and where any threat to such basic systems would endanger the entire organization.

name: Cross-Site Scripting
description: Cross-Site Scripting is a type of security vulnerability that occurs when malicious code is injected into a web application, which is then executed by unsuspecting users in their web browsers. It can lead to data theft and other attacks.

name: Cryptanalysis
description: Cryptanalysis is the study of analyzing and breaking cryptographic systems or codes to uncover their content without the knowledge of the key. It is often used to test the security of encryption methods.

name: Cryptography
description: Cryptography is the science and practice of secure communication techniques that hide information from unauthorized access. It involves encryption and decryption methods to protect data from eavesdropping or tampering.

name: Cryptojacking
description: Cryptojacking consists of hackers using the computing power of a compromised device to generate or “mine” cryptocurrency without the owner’s knowledge. Mining can be performed either by installing a malicious program on the target computer or through various kinds of fileless malware. Sometimes attackers take over part of the computer’s processing power when a page containing a special mining script is opened. Cryptojacking has been known to occur when viewing online ads or solving a CAPTCHA.

name: Cyber Attack
description: A cyberattack is a malicious attempt to breach a computer system, network, or device to gain unauthorized access, steal data, disrupt operations, or cause harm. Cyberattacks come in various forms, such as malware, phishing, and DDoS attacks.

name: Cyber Audit
description: A cybersecurity audit is a systematic examination of an organization's cybersecurity policies, procedures, and controls to assess their effectiveness and compliance with relevant standards and regulations.

name: Cyber Bullying
description: Cyberbullying is the use of electronic means, primarily messaging and social media platforms, to bully and harass a victim. Cyberbullying has become a major problem, especially affecting young people, as it allows bullies to magnify their aggressive behavior, publicly ridicule victims on a large scale, and carry out damaging activities in a way that is difficult for parents and teachers to detect.

name: Cyber Crime
description: Cybercrime involves illegal activities committed using computers or digital technology. These crimes include hacking, identity theft, online fraud, and other malicious actions conducted in cyberspace.

name: Cyber Defense
description: Cyber defense refers to the strategies and technologies employed to protect computer systems and networks from cyberattacks and security breaches. It includes measures such as firewalls, intrusion detection systems, and incident response protocols.

name: Cyber Espoinage
description: Cyber espionage involves the unauthorized gathering of sensitive information or intellectual property by individuals, organizations, or nation-states for strategic or economic purposes.

name: Cyber Forensis
description: Cyber forensics, also known as digital forensics, is the process of collecting, analyzing, and preserving digital evidence to investigate cybercrimes or security incidents

name: Cyber Incident Response
description: Cyber incident response is the process of reacting to and managing a cybersecurity incident or breach. It involves containing the incident, analyzing the impact, and taking steps to recover and prevent future occurrences.

name: Cyber Insurance
description: Cyber insurance is a type of insurance that helps organizations mitigate the financial impact of cyber incidents. It can cover costs associated with data breaches, legal liabilities, and recovery efforts.

name: Cyber Kill Chain
description: The cyber kill chain is a concept used in cybersecurity to describe the stages a cyberattack goes through, from reconnaissance to data exfiltration. Understanding these stages helps in preventing and detecting attacks.

name: Cyber Threat
description: A cyber threat is a potential danger or risk to computer systems, networks, or data. It can be a specific vulnerability or an active attack by threat actors.

name: Cyber Threat Hunting
description: Cyber threat hunting is a proactive approach to cybersecurity where experts actively search for signs of potential threats or intrusions within an organization's network, often before those threats are identified by automated security tools.

name: Cyber Threat Intelligence
description: Cyber threat intelligence is information and analysis about potential cybersecurity threats, including the tactics, techniques, and procedures used by threat actors. It helps organizations prepare for and respond to cyber threats effectively.

name: Cyber Training
description: Cybersecurity training provides individuals and employees with knowledge and skills to protect against cyber threats. It covers topics like secure browsing, safe email practices, and password management.

name: Cyber Vulnerability
description: A cyber vulnerability is a weakness or flaw in a computer system, software, or network that could be exploited by cybercriminals or threat actors to gain unauthorized access or cause harm.

name: Cybersecurity
description: Cybersecurity relates to processes employed to safeguard and secure assets used to carry information of an organization from being stolen or attacked. It requires extensive knowledge of possible threats such as viruses or other malicious objects. Identity management, risk management, and incident management form the crux of the cybersecurity strategies of an organization.

name: Cybersecurity Architecture
description: refers to the design and structure of an organization's security measures and strategies to protect its digital assets and data from various threats and vulnerabilities. It typically includes elements like firewalls, intrusion detection systems, encryption, access controls, and incident response plans. A well-designed cybersecurity architecture is crucial for safeguarding against cyberattacks and ensuring the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of sensitive information. It's a complex and evolving field, with a focus on proactive defense and risk management.

name: Cybersecurity Assessment
description: A cybersecurity assessment is an evaluation of an organization's security posture, including vulnerabilities, threats, and protective measures. It helps identify areas of improvement in cybersecurity.

name: Cybersecurity Awareness
description: Cybersecurity awareness involves educating individuals within an organization about the importance of cybersecurity and how to recognize and respond to potential threats. It aims to create a security-conscious culture.

name: Cybersecurity Awareness Campaign
description: A cybersecurity awareness campaign is a strategic effort to promote awareness and understanding of cybersecurity issues among a specific audience, such as employees or the general public. It often includes communication, training, and engagement activities to improve cybersecurity awareness and behavior.

name: Cybersecurity Awareness Month
description: Cybersecurity Awareness Month is an annual campaign held in October to raise awareness about the importance of cybersecurity. It aims to educate individuals and organizations about online threats, best practices for staying safe online, and the role of cybersecurity in our increasingly digital world.

name: Cybersecurity Awareness Program
description: A cybersecurity awareness program is a structured initiative within an organization to educate its employees and stakeholders about cybersecurity best practices. It helps in creating a security-conscious culture and reduces the likelihood of security incidents caused by human error.

name: Cybersecurity Awareness Training
description: Cybersecurity awareness training involves educating individuals, often employees, about cybersecurity risks and best practices. It helps them recognize threats and take appropriate security measures.

name: Cybersecurity Best Practices
description: Cybersecurity best practices refer to recommended guidelines and methods for securing computer systems and data. These practices are based on industry standards and expertise and help reduce the risk of cyber threats.

name: Cybersecurity Certification
description: A cybersecurity certification is a formal recognition of an individual's knowledge and skills in the field. Certifications like CISSP, CISM, and CompTIA Security+ are widely recognized and demonstrate competence in various aspects of cybersecurity.

name: Cybersecurity Consultant
description: A cybersecurity consultant is an expert who provides advice, assessments, and guidance to organizations on how to improve their cybersecurity practices. They often assist in identifying vulnerabilities and suggesting security solutions.

name: Cybersecurity Control
description: Cybersecurity controls are measures and safeguards put in place to protect an organization's information systems and data. These controls can include technologies, policies, procedures, and practices designed to mitigate cybersecurity risks.

name: Cybersecurity Engineer
description: A cybersecurity engineer is a professional responsible for designing, implementing, and maintaining an organization's security infrastructure. They work on creating and managing systems and tools to protect against cyber threats.

name: Cybersecurity Expert
description: A cybersecurity expert is an individual with in-depth knowledge and expertise in the field of cybersecurity. They are well-versed in various security technologies, threats, and best practices, and often play a critical role in protecting systems and data.

name: Cybersecurity Governance
description: Cybersecurity governance is the framework and structure that guides an organization's cybersecurity efforts. It includes defining roles, responsibilities, policies, and decision-making processes related to security.

name: Cybersecurity Hygiene
description: Cyber hygiene refers to the practices and habits individuals and organizations adopt to maintain a clean and secure digital environment. It involves actions like keeping software up to date, using strong passwords, and being cautious online to prevent cyber threats.

name: Cybersecurity Incident
description: A cybersecurity incident is any event or occurrence that compromises the confidentiality, integrity, or availability of data or computer systems. It may involve breaches, data theft, or other security breaches.

name: Cybersecurity Framework
description: A cybersecurity framework is a structured set of guidelines and best practices for managing and improving an organization's cybersecurity program. Frameworks help organizations assess and enhance their security posture.

name: Cybersecurity Operations
description: Cybersecurity operations refer to the day-to-day activities and tasks that maintain the security of an organization's systems and data. It includes monitoring, incident response, and ongoing security management.

name: Cybersecurity Policy
description: A cybersecurity policy is a set of rules and guidelines that outline an organization's approach to cybersecurity. It defines how data and systems should be protected, and it often includes incident response procedures.

name: Cybersecurity Resilience
description: Cyber resilience is the ability of an organization to withstand and recover from cyberattacks or security incidents. It involves measures to minimize the impact of threats and maintain operations.

name: Cybersecurity Risk Assessment
description: A cybersecurity risk assessment is the process of identifying, evaluating, and prioritizing potential cybersecurity risks within an organization. It helps in making informed decisions about risk mitigation.

name: Cybersecurity Risk Management
description: Cybersecurity risk management involves identifying, assessing, and prioritizing potential threats and vulnerabilities to an organization's digital assets. It aims to minimize these risks through proactive strategies and controls.

name: Cybersecurity Strategy
description: A cybersecurity strategy is a comprehensive plan that outlines an organization's long-term approach to managing and mitigating cybersecurity risks. It typically includes goals, objectives, and a roadmap for improving security.

name: Cybersecurity Threat Assessment
description: A cybersecurity threat assessment involves identifying and evaluating potential threats to an organization's IT infrastructure and data. This assessment helps organizations understand their vulnerabilities and take proactive steps to mitigate risks.

name: Dark Data
description: Dark data refers to unstructured, unused, or underutilized data that organizations generate but do not leverage for decision-making or analysis. Managing and analyzing dark data can reveal valuable insights and improve data utilization.

name: Dark Fiber
description: Dark fiber refers to unused or unlit optical fiber cables within a network infrastructure. These unused fibers can be 'lit' or activated when additional network capacity is needed, making it a cost-effective way to expand network capabilities.

name: Darknet
description: The darknet, in the context of cybersecurity, is a private network built on top of the internet and often accessed using specialized software like Tor. It provides anonymity and privacy and is used for various purposes, including legitimate privacy protection and illegal activities.

name: Dark Web
description: Dark Web is encrypted parts of the internet that are not indexed by search engines, most notoriously used by all types of criminals including; pedophiles, illicit human and contraband traffickers, and cyber criminals, to communicate and share information without being detected or identified by law enforcement. Malware of all types can be purchased on the dark web. A subset of the deep web, which can be accessed by anyone with the correct URL, dark web pages need special software (ex. Tor) with the correct decryption key and access rights and knowledge to find content. Users of the dark web remain almost completely anonymous due to its P2P network connections which makes network activity very difficult to trace.

name: Database Encryption
description: Database encryption is the process of applying encryption to the data stored within a database. It ensures that sensitive information is protected from unauthorized access by converting it into an unreadable format, which can only be decrypted with the appropriate key.

name: Database Security
description: Database security involves measures and practices designed to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data stored in databases. This includes access controls, encryption, and auditing to prevent unauthorized access and data breaches.

name: Data Breach
description: A Data Breach is the event of a hacker successfully exploits a network or device vulnerability and gains access to its files and data or is an incident in which unauthorized individuals gain access to sensitive, confidential, or protected information, such as personal data or company secrets. This breach may result in data theft, exposure, or compromise.

name: Data Classification
description: Data classification is the process of categorizing data based on its sensitivity, value, and importance. It helps organizations manage and protect data effectively by applying appropriate security measures to different types of data.

name: Data Custodian
description: A data custodian is an individual or entity responsible for safeguarding and managing data on behalf of its owner or stakeholders. They ensure that data is stored, processed, and protected according to established policies and security standards.

name: Data Encryption
description: Data encryption is the process of converting data into a secure, unreadable format to protect it from unauthorized access. Encrypted data can only be decrypted with the appropriate decryption key, ensuring data confidentiality and security.

name: Data-at-rest Encryption
description: Data-at-rest encryption is a security measure that protects data stored on physical or digital storage media, such as hard drives, databases, or cloud storage, by encrypting it. This ensures that even if the storage medium is stolen or compromised, the data remains secure.

name: Data Exfiltration
description: Data exfiltration is the unauthorized transfer or theft of data from a computer or network to an external location. It is often associated with cyberattacks or insider threats where sensitive data is taken outside the organization.

name: Data Integrity
description: Data Integrity is a broad term that refers to the maintenance and assurance of data quality. This includes the accuracy and consistency of data over its entire lifecycle. Data Integrity is an important part of the design, implementation, and use of any data system that stores, processes, or retrieves information. The term is broad in scope and may have widely different meanings depending on the specific context

name: Data Leakage
description: Data leakage, also known as data leakage or data loss, occurs when sensitive or confidential data is unintentionally or maliciously disclosed to unauthorized individuals or systems. This can happen through various means, including data breaches or accidental exposure.

name: Data Loss Provention
description: Data Loss Prevention (DLP) is an umbrella term for a collection of security tools, processes, and procedures that aim to prevent sensitive data from falling into unauthorized or malicious hands. DLP aims at preventing such occurrences through various techniques such as strict access controls on resources, blocking or monitoring email attachments, preventing network file exchange to external systems, blocking cut-and-paste, disabling the use of social networks and encrypting stored data.

name: Data Masking
description: Data masking is a data security technique that involves replacing sensitive or confidential information in a dataset with fictional or pseudonymous data while maintaining the dataset's structure and functionality. It is used to protect sensitive data during non-production use, such as development or testing.

name: Data Retention
description: Data retention is a data management policy that defines how long data should be stored or archived. It considers legal and business requirements and helps organizations determine the appropriate timeframe for keeping data before deletion or archiving.

name: Data Residency
description: Data residency refers to the physical or geographical location where data is stored and processed. Compliance regulations and legal requirements often dictate data residency, especially in the context of cross-border data storage and privacy laws.

name: Data Sanitization
description: Data sanitization is the process of securely and irreversibly removing data from storage devices, making it impossible to recover. This is crucial when disposing of or reusing storage media to prevent data breaches.

name: Data Shredding
description: Data shredding, or secure data destruction, is the process of permanently and securely erasing data from storage devices, making it unrecoverable. It typically involves overwriting data multiple times to ensure complete removal.

name: Data Spillage
description: Data spillage refers to the unintentional exposure or leakage of sensitive or confidential information. It can occur due to human error, misconfigured systems, or inadequate security measures, potentially leading to data breaches.

name: Data Theft
description: Data Theft is the deliberate theft of sensitive data by nefarious actors.

name: Data Wiping
description: Data wiping, also known as data erasure, is the process of securely and permanently removing data from a storage device, such as a hard drive or mobile device. It involves overwriting the data to prevent any future recovery, ensuring data privacy and security.

name: DDoS
description: A Denial of Service (DoS) or Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack is when one or more compromised systems launch a flooding attack on a remote target(s), in an attempt to overload network resources and disrupt service. Some DDoS attacks have caused prolonged, complete service shutdowns of major online operators.

name: Decentralized Identity
description: Decentralized identity is a concept that allows individuals to control and manage their digital identities without relying on a central authority. It provides a more secure and privacy-focused way for users to interact online while maintaining control over their personal data.

name: Deception Technology
description: Deception technology is a cybersecurity approach that involves setting up traps, decoys, and false information within a network to detect and mislead potential attackers. It helps organizations identify and respond to threats more effectively.

name: Decryption
description: Decryption is the process of converting encrypted data back into its original, readable format using a decryption key. It is the opposite of encryption, which transforms data into an unreadable form for security.

name: Decoy Network
description: A decoy network is a security strategy where a network is deliberately set up with false information, systems, or vulnerabilities to divert and mislead potential attackers. It is used to detect and deceive malicious actors.

name: DeepFake
description: A piece of audio or video that has been altered and changed to make it seem authentic or credible. The most perilous aspect of the prevalence of deepfakes is that they can easily convince individuals into believing a particular tale or idea, which may lead to user behavior that has a greater impact on society at large, such as in the political or financial spheres.

name: Default Password
description: A default password is a pre-configured, often generic password that is set by manufacturers or service providers for various devices and applications. These passwords are intended to be changed by users to enhance security. Failing to change default passwords can leave systems vulnerable to unauthorized access.

name: Defense In Depth
description: Defense in depth is a cybersecurity strategy that involves implementing multiple layers of security measures to protect an organization's IT systems. This approach aims to mitigate risks by ensuring that even if one layer is breached, other layers remain intact to safeguard the system.

name: Denial of Service
description: A Denial of Service (DoS) attack is a cyberattack in which the attacker floods a network, system, or website with traffic or requests, causing it to become overwhelmed and unavailable to legitimate users.

name: Detection and Response
description: Network Detection and Response is a security solution category used by organizations to detect malicious network activity, perform a forensic investigation to determine the root cause, and then respond and mitigate the threat.

name: Dictionary Attack
description: A dictionary attack is a type of password-cracking method in which an attacker uses a list of common words, phrases, or combinations as potential passwords to gain unauthorized access to a system or account.

name: Diffie-Hellman Key Exchange
description: The Diffie-Hellman Key Exchange is a cryptographic protocol used to secure communication over an insecure channel. It allows two parties to establish a shared secret key without exchanging the key directly, providing confidentiality and security.

name: Digital Certificate Authority
description: A Digital Certificate Authority is a trusted entity that issues digital certificates to verify the authenticity and identity of individuals, organizations, or devices in digital communication. CAs play a crucial role in ensuring secure and encrypted online transactions. Digital identity refers to the online representation of an individual, organization, or device. It includes information and attributes used for authentication, authorization, and validation in digital transactions and interactions.

name: Digital Identity
description: Digital identity refers to the online representation of an individual, organization, or device. It includes information and attributes used for authentication, authorization, and validation in digital transactions and interactions.

name: Digital Forensics
description: Digital Forensics is the process of procuring, analyzing, and interpreting electronic data for the purpose of presenting it as legal evidence in a court of law.

name: Digital Rights Management (DRM)
description: DRM is a set of technologies and methods used to protect and manage the copyright and intellectual property rights of digital content, such as music, videos, and ebooks. DRM controls access, copying, and distribution of digital content to prevent unauthorized use.

name: Digital Signature
description: A digital signature is a cryptographic technique used to verify the authenticity and integrity of a digital document or message. It provides a means to confirm that the content has not been tampered with and that it was created by the claimed sender.

name: Digital Transformation
description: Digital Transformation is the process of using digital technologies to create or modify business processes and customer experiences to keep up-to-date with current business and market requirements.

name: Digital Wallet
description: A digital wallet is a software application or service that allows users to store, manage, and make digital payments or transactions securely. It can hold payment card information, digital currencies, loyalty cards, and more.

name: Directory Transversal
description: Directory traversal, also known as path traversal or dot-dot-slash attack, is a type of security vulnerability that occurs when an attacker can access files and directories outside the intended directory structure. It can lead to unauthorized access to sensitive data or system files.

name: Disaster Recovery
description: Disaster recovery is a comprehensive strategy and set of procedures for restoring IT systems, data, and business operations after a catastrophic event, such as a natural disaster, cyberattack, or hardware failure. It ensures business continuity and data resilience.

name: Distributed Ledger Technology (DLT)
description: Distributed Ledger Technology is a decentralized system for recording and verifying transactions across multiple nodes or participants. It is best known for its application in cryptocurrencies like blockchain, but it has a wide range of uses, including supply chain management and voting systems.

name: Domain
description: A series of computers and associated peripherals (routers, printers, scanners), that are all connected as one entity.

name: Domain Hijacking
description: Domain hijacking occurs when an attacker gains control of a domain name without the owner's consent. This can lead to unauthorized access to websites, email services, or other online assets associated with the hijacked domain.

name: Domain Name Systems (DNS)
description: The Domain Name System is a decentralized hierarchical naming system used to translate human-readable domain names (like www.example.com) into IP addresses that computers use to identify each other on the internet. DNS is essential for internet navigation.

name: Domain Name Systems (DNS) Exfiltration
description: Domain Name System (DNS) Exfiltration is a lower-level attack on DNS servers to gain unauthorized access. Such attacks are difficult to detect and can lead to loss of data.

name: Drive-By Download Attack
description: Drive-by Downloads or attacks are a common method of spreading malware. Cybercriminals look for insecure websites and plant a malicious script into HTTP or PHP code on one of the pages. This script may install malware directly onto the computer of someone who visits the site, or it may take the form of an IFRAME that re-directs the victim to a site controlled by the cybercriminals. Such attacks are called ‘drive-by downloads’ because they require no action on the part of the victim — beyond simply visiting the compromised website: they have infected automatically (and silently) if their computer is vulnerable in some way (e.g., if they have failed to apply a security update to one of their applications).

name: DMZ (Demilitarized Zone)
description: A DMZ is a network segment that sits between an organization's internal network and the external, untrusted network (typically the internet). It is used to provide an additional layer of security and house services that need public access while isolating them from the internal network.

name: DNS Security
description: DNS security encompasses technologies and practices aimed at protecting the Domain Name System (DNS) from threats, including DNS spoofing and cache poisoning, to ensure the integrity of domain name resolution.

name: Dumpster Diving
description: Dumpster diving is a physical method of gathering sensitive information or discarded materials by searching through trash or dumpsters. Attackers may engage in dumpster diving to find documents or data that can be exploited for malicious purposes.

name: Dwell Time
description: Dwell time is the duration between when a cybersecurity threat enters a network and when it is detected and mitigated. A shorter dwell time indicates a more effective security response, while longer dwell times can lead to more extensive damage from cyberattacks.

name: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP)
description: DHCP is a network protocol that automates the assignment of IP addresses and other network configuration settings to devices on a network. It simplifies the process of connecting devices to anetwork by dynamically allocating IP addresses.

name: Eavesdropping
description: Eavesdropping is the unauthorized interception of electronic communications, such as phone calls or network traffic, with the intent to monitor or obtain information without the knowledge or consent of the parties involved.

name: Egress Filtering
description: Egress filtering is a network security measure that controls the flow of data leaving a network or system. It is used to monitor and restrict outbound network traffic to prevent data leakage and unauthorized communication.

name: Egress Point
description: An egress point is a network location or device through which data exits a network and enters another network or the internet. Egress points are important for monitoring and controlling the flow of data leaving a network to ensure security and compliance with policies. They play a crucial role in data protection, traffic filtering, and threat detection.

name: Egress Traffic
description: Egress traffic refers to the data leaving a network or system and traveling to external destinations, such as other networks or the internet. Monitoring and controlling egress traffic is important for security and compliance.

name: Email Phishing
description: Email phishing is a type of cyberattack that involves sending deceptive or fraudulent emails to individuals or organizations, typically with the aim of tricking recipients into revealing sensitive information, such as login credentials, financial details, or personal data. These emails often appear to be from legitimate sources, but they are designed to deceive and exploit the recipient's trust.

name: Email Security Gateway
description: An email security gateway is a network device or service that filters and secures email traffic. It protects against various email-based threats, such as spam, phishing, malware, and other malicious content. It acts as a barrier between the organization's email infrastructure and external email sources.

name: Email Security Policy
description: An email security policy is a set of guidelines and rules that an organization implements to protect its email communication. It outlines best practices for email usage, including rules for encryption, authentication, spam filtering, and acceptable use, to maintain the security and integrity of email communications.

name: Email Spoofing
description: Email spoofing is a technique in which an attacker manipulates the sender's email address to make it appear as if the email is coming from a different source. This is often used in phishing attacks to deceive recipients.

name: Embedded System Security
description: Embedded system security is a branch of cybersecurity that focuses on protecting computing systems integrated into various devices and equipment, including IoT (Internet of Things) devices, medical devices, industrial machinery, and automotive systems. These embedded systems often have resource limitations but are vulnerable to security threats. Ensuring their security involves implementing measures to safeguard data, control access, and protect against vulnerabilities unique to embedded systems.

name: End-to-End Encryption
description: End-to-end encryption (E2E) is a method of secure communication that ensures data is encrypted on the sender's side and can only be decrypted by the intended recipient. It prevents intermediaries, including service providers, from accessing the data in transit.

name: Encrypted Communication
description: Encrypted communication is the secure transmission of data over a network, ensuring that the information is protected from unauthorized access. It involves using encryption techniques to encode the data before transmission and decode it at the receiving end with the appropriate decryption key.

name: Encrypted File
description: An encrypted file is a digital file that has been transformed into a format that is unreadable without the correct decryption key or passphrase. This is done to protect the file's contents from unauthorized access or viewing. Encrypted files are commonly used to secure sensitive data.

name: Encrypted Traffic Analysis
description: Encrypted traffic analysis is the process of analyzing network traffic, even when it's encrypted. While the content of encrypted data remains hidden, various characteristics of the encrypted traffic can be analyzed to detect patterns or anomalies that may indicate security threats or other issues.

name: Encrypted Tunnel
description: An encrypted tunnel is a secure communication channel created over an insecure network, such as the internet. It ensures that data transmitted between two points is encrypted and protected from eavesdropping. Virtual Private Networks (VPNs) often use encrypted tunnels to secure data transmission between devices or networks.

name: Encryption
description: Encryption is a process of maintaining data confidentiality by converting plain data into secret code with the help of an encryption algorithm. Only users with the appropriate decryption key can unscramble and access encrypted data or cipher text.

name: Encryption Algorithm
description: An encryption algorithm is a well-defined, mathematical procedure used to transform plain or unencrypted data into a secure, ciphertext format. Encryption algorithms rely on keys and specific mathematical operations to make data unintelligible to unauthorized parties. The strength and security of encryption depend on the algorithm's complexity and the length and management of encryption keys.

name: Encryption at Rest
description: Encryption at rest is the practice of encrypting data when it is stored on non-volatile storage devices, such as hard drives, solid-state drives, or databases. The goal is to protect data even when it is not actively being used. It safeguards the information from physical theft or unauthorized access by rendering it unreadable without the appropriate decryption key.

name: Encryption Backdoor
description: An encryption backdoor is a deliberate vulnerability or weakness intentionally inserted into an encryption system or software, typically by design, to allow authorized parties to bypass the encryption and access protected data. This concept is highly controversial, as it can undermine the security and privacy of encrypted information and can lead to concerns regarding government surveillance and data protection.

name: Encryption Decryption
description: Encryption is the process of converting data into a secure, unreadable format using an encryption algorithm and a key. Decryption is the reverse process of converting the encrypted data back into its original, readable form using the appropriate decryption key. This is a fundamental technique for data security.

name: Encryption Key
description: An encryption key is a piece of information used by encryption algorithms to both encrypt and decrypt data. It serves as the basis for the encryption and decryption processes, and the security of the data largely depends on the strength of the key.

name: Encryption Key Exchange
description: Encryption key exchange is the secure process of transmitting cryptographic keys between parties engaged in secure communication. It is a crucial step in setting up secure connections and ensuring that both the sender and receiver have the necessary keys to encrypt and decrypt data. Secure key exchange methods are essential for preventing eavesdropping and unauthorized access to transmitted data.

name: Encryption Key Management
description: Encryption key management is a comprehensive process that encompasses the generation, distribution, storage, and protection of cryptographic keys used in encryption and decryption. It involves establishing secure key generation methods, safeguarding keys from unauthorized access, regularly rotating keys, and ensuring their availability when data needs to be encrypted or decrypted. Effective key management is essential for the security and integrity of encrypted data.

name: Encryption Key Rotation
description: Encryption key rotation is the practice of regularly changing the cryptographic keys used for encryption and decryption. It is done to enhance security by reducing the window of vulnerability and making it more challenging for attackers to decrypt data that may have been captured with older keys.

name: Encryption Protocol
description: An encryption protocol is a set of rules, procedures, and conventions that govern how data is securely transmitted and protected during communication over a network or the internet. These protocols dictate how encryption keys are exchanged, how data is encrypted and decrypted, and how authentication and integrity checks are performed to ensure secure and private communication between parties.

name: Encryption Security Software
description: Endpoint security software refers to a category of cybersecurity tools designed to protect individual devices (endpoints), such as computers, smartphones, and servers, from various security threats. This software typically includes features like antivirus, anti-malware, firewall, intrusion detection, and data loss prevention to safeguard endpoints from attacks.

name: Encryption Standard
description: Encryption standard refers to a set of rules and protocols used to encrypt data for security purposes. It specifies how data should be transformed into a coded format, making it unreadable to anyone without the proper decryption key. Common encryption standards include AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) and RSA (Rivest-Shamir-Adleman).

name: Encryption Strength
description: Encryption strength refers to the level of security provided by an encryption algorithm. It is determined by factors such as the complexity of the encryption algorithm, the length of encryption keys, and the quality of key management practices. Strong encryption is resistant to unauthorized decryption, making it a fundamental component of data security in various applications.

name: End-of-Life (EOL) Software
description: software refers to software that has reached the end of its official support and maintenance period. This means that the software vendor no longer provides updates, patches, or security fixes, making it potentially vulnerable to security threats. Users are encouraged to upgrade or migrate to a supported version or alternative software.

name: Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR)
description: Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR) are tools for protecting computer endpoints from potential threats. EDR platforms comprise software and networking tools for detecting suspicious endpoint activities, usually via continuous network monitoring.

name: Endpoint Detection and Response Solution (EDRS)
description: An EDR (Endpoint Detection and Response) solution is a cybersecurity tool designed to monitor and respond to security threats and incidents at the endpoint level, such as individual devices (e.g., computers, servers). EDR solutions provide real-time visibility into endpoint activities, enabling the detection of suspicious behavior. They also offer response capabilities to mitigate threats, investigate incidents, and contain security breaches effectively.

name: Endpoint Protection
description: Endpoint Protection refers to a system for network security management that monitors network endpoints, hardware devices such as workstations and mobile devices from which a network is accessed.

name: Endpoint Security Management
description: Endpoint security management involves the centralized management and protection of endpoints (devices) within a network. It includes tasks like deploying security software, monitoring for threats, applying patches, and enforcing security policies on laptops, desktops, and mobile devices to safeguard against cyberattacks.

name: End-User Security Training
description: End-user security training refers to educating individuals within an organization, such as employees or users, on best practices for maintaining information security. This training aims to raise awareness about potential threats, such as phishing and malware, and instructs users on how to recognize and respond to security incidents effectively. It plays a critical role in enhancing an organization's overall security posture.

name: Enterprise Network Security
description: Enterprise network security is the practice of safeguarding an organization's computer networks and information systems from various threats, including cyberattacks, data breaches, and unauthorized access. It encompasses a range of security measures and technologies to protect sensitive data, network infrastructure, and communication channels within a large-scale business or enterprise environment.

name: Enumeration
description: Enumeration is a systematic process of extracting information about a target system, network, or device. It involves identifying and listing various resources, services, and entities within the system. Enumeration is often used in the field of computer security to gather valuable information about a system's configuration, potential vulnerabilities, and the services it offers. This information can be critical for attackers seeking to exploit weaknesses in a system or for security professionals looking to assess and improve system security.

name: Escrow Key
description: An escrow key is a cryptographic key held in escrow by a trusted third party. It is typically used in scenarios where access to the key is needed for specific purposes, such as data recovery or legal requirements, but is not accessible by the key owner. Escrow keys are often used in encryption systems to ensure key recovery in case of emergencies.

name: Ethical Hacker Certification
description: Ethical hacker certification is a credential awarded to individuals who have demonstrated their expertise in cybersecurity and ethical hacking practices. One of the most well-known certifications in this field is the Certified Ethical Hacker (CEH), which certifies professionals in ethical hacking and penetration testing.

name: Ethical Hacking
description: Ethical hacking, also known as penetration testing or white-hat hacking, involves authorized individuals or cybersecurity professionals testing a system's security by attempting to identify and exploit vulnerabilities. The goal is to find and fix security weaknesses before malicious hackers can exploit them.

name: Event Correlation
description: Event correlation is a process in cybersecurity and network monitoring where data from various sources, such as security logs and sensors, is analyzed to identify patterns and relationships. This helps in detecting and responding to security incidents by linking related events and uncovering potential threats or anomalies.

name: Event Log
description: An event log is a record or chronology of events and activities that occur on a computer, network, or system. Event logs are essential for monitoring system behavior, diagnosing issues, and enhancing security. They contain information about user logins, system errors, security incidents, and other relevant activities. Analyzing event logs is a common practice in cybersecurity to detect and respond to security breaches and anomalies.

name: Evil Maid Attack
description: An evil maid attack is a type of physical security threat in which an attacker gains unauthorized access to a target's device or computer when it is left unattended in a physical location, such as a hotel room. The attacker may tamper with the device or install malicious software to compromise its security. This attack underscores the importance of physical security measures to protect devices and data.

name: Evil Twin
description: An evil twin is a rogue Wi-Fi access point that mimics a legitimate network, enticing users to connect to it. Once connected, it can intercept data and launch attacks on the connected devices.

name: Exfiltration
description: Exfiltration refers to the unauthorized and often covert extraction or theft of data from a computer, network, or organization. It involves the removal of sensitive or confidential information from its intended location to an external or unauthorized destination. Exfiltration can occur through various methods, including network transfers, physical theft, or social engineering attacks. Detecting and preventing data exfiltration is a key concern for cybersecurity efforts.

name: Exfiltration Detection
description: Exfiltration detection is the process of identifying unauthorized data transfers or leaks from a network. It involves monitoring network traffic and system logs to detect when sensitive or confidential data is being illicitly removed or transmitted outside the organization.

name: Exploit
description: An exploit is taking advantage of a vulnerability or flaw in a network system to penetrate or attack it. It is a means of attack on a computer system, either a series of commands, malicious software, or piece of infected data. Note that in this context, “exploit” is a noun, not a verb, as in “The hacker used a malware exploit to gain access to the credit card’s server.”

name: Exploit Kit
description: An exploit kit is a collection of pre-packaged software tools and exploits used by cybercriminals to automate and streamline the process of exploiting vulnerabilities in computer systems and software. These kits are designed to deliver malware, compromise systems, and gain unauthorized access by taking advantage of known security weaknesses.

name: Exploit Payload
description: An exploit payload refers to the malicious code or software delivered by an attacker's exploit. Exploits are used to take advantage of vulnerabilities in a system or software, and the payload is the part that carries out the attacker's malicious objectives, such as installing malware or gaining unauthorized access.

name: Exponential Authentication
description: Exponential authentication is an advanced authentication method that leverages multiple factors and layers of security to verify the identity of a user or device. It typically combines traditional factors like passwords with additional factors such as biometrics, smart cards, or behavioral analysis. The goal is to provide a highly secure and robust authentication process.

name: Exposure Assessment
description: Exposure assessment is a systematic evaluation of potential risks and vulnerabilities within an organization's information technology infrastructure. It involves identifying and quantifying potential threats and assessing the likelihood and impact of security incidents, helping organizations prioritize security measures.

name: Face Recogniton
description: Face recognition, a biometric authentication method, identifies and verifies individuals based on their facial features. It analyzes unique facial characteristics and compares them to stored templates to grant access or confirm identity. It's used in access control and device unlocking.

name: Failover
description: Failover is a redundancy mechanism used in networking and cybersecurity to ensure high availability. When a primary system or service fails, a failover system or backup takes over, minimizing downtime and maintaining continuous operations.

name: False Negative
description: A false negative in cybersecurity occurs when a security system fails to detect a genuine threat or malicious activity, marking it as safe or non-threatening. False negatives can pose a significant security risk because actual threats go unnoticed.

name: False Positve
description: In the context of cybersecurity, a false positive occurs when a security system incorrectly identifies benign or legitimate activity as a threat. It can lead to unnecessary alerts and additional investigation efforts.

name: Faraday Cage
description: A Faraday cage is a shielded enclosure or structure designed to block electromagnetic fields and signals. In cybersecurity, it is used to protect electronic equipment and data from electromagnetic interference and to prevent data leakage through electromagnetic eavesdropping.

name: Fast Identity Online (FIDO)
description: Fast Identity Online (FIDO) is a set of open authentication standards that enable a service provider to leverage existing technologies for passwordless authentication.

name: Fast Identity Online 2 (FIDO2)
description: FIDO2 is an authentication standard that enables passwordless and strong, public-key-based authentication for online services. It combines the Web Authentication (WebAuthn) and Client-to-Authenticator Protocol (CTAP) to enhance online security and user convenience.

name: Federated Identity
description: Federated identity is an authentication and authorization mechanism that allows users to access multiple applications or services using a single set of credentials.
